title: Tibullus 1 2 - the poet and the door

content.description:
Directions: Read the following selection carefully for comprehension. The selection is followed by a number of related questions and incomplete statements. Select the best answer or completion.

A heartsick lover complains.

Nam posita est nostrae custodia saeva puellae,

clauditur et durā ianua firma serā.1

Ianua difficilis domini, te verberet imber,

te Iovis imperio fulmina missa petant.

(5) Ianua, iam pateas uni mihi victa querellis,

neu furtim verso cardine aperta sones.

Et mala si qua tibi dixit dementia nostra,

ignoscas; capiti sint precor illa meo.

Te meminisse decet quae plurima voce peregi

(10) supplice cum posti2 ﬂorida serta3 darem.

Tu quoque ne timide custodes, Delia, falle.

Audendum est: fortes adiuvat ipsa Venus.

1 sera, -ae, f.: door bolt, bar

2 postis, -is, m.: doorpost, door

3 serta, n. pl.: garlands
content.question: In line 5 (Ianua . . . querellis), the poet feels that the door may

choices.label: complain that there is only one poet
complain that it has been left open
be won over by his complaints

content.answer: be won over by his complaints

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2
